subject: Re: [junit] Using JUnit Inside Application Server?
msgSnippet: ... There is no reason why you can t run your tests inside your container, and if you are going to test an application that runs inside a container, it s
messageBody:
On 11/2/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
> Extract as much as possible to classes that can be tested outside of the
> application server. The majority of the behaviour you are developing can
> be
> and should be ignorant of wheter it runs in an applicationserver or not.
> For
> system tests there is Cactus and MockEJB. I'm not convinced that it is a
> good idea to use those frameworks. I never felt had the need.
>
> I think in those cases deploy your application and run your tests as a
> client. Perhaps using FIT or some other acceptance-testing framework.
> Those
> tests are typically run more seldomly than your unit-tests.
>
> This is just my opinion on a way forward. I'm sure those who disagree will
> speak up soon :)


There is no reason why you can't run your tests inside your container, and
if you are going to test an application that runs inside a container, it's
probably wise to run your tests there as well. The easiest way is probably
to package your tests in their own application (or bundle them with the
application you are trying to test) and run them as a regular Java EE
application.

--
Cédric
